rComments: You can tell he loves criminal law. Knows his cases and the Criminal Code very well. Compassionate and cares about students. Personable and a good lecturer. Class is more lecture than discussion but he will stop to answer questions. Fair exams. Readings are pretty heavy but still managed to finish them. Thank god for headnotes.

I had no interest in criminal law (and still don't) but Professor David made first year crim so enjoyable. I looked forward to our  classes every week. There is a lot of content covered but he's always happy to go back and clarify something you may have missed. He managed the bimodal format better than all our other professors this year as well.

Professor David is an extremely caring and enthusiastic lecturer. You can tell he really loves what he teaches and truly cares about his students. He always takes the time to answer students questions both in-class and through email. I really fell in love with criminal law after taking his class and would highly recommend that you take his course!

You can tell Professor David cares about and enjoys teaching his students. He patiently answered any and all questions during class and would make time on the weekend for exam review if it would help students. Above all, I can say that I learned a lot in his class. Great introduction into Criminal Law.

People LOVED to complain about the fact that he did not use PowerPoint slides, I hate to say, but he is neither the first nor the last professor to do this! You will not find a professor in Canada more caring, relatable, and passionate than Professor David. If you do your readings and attend lectures, you will do fantastic. You must take his class

Professor David is extremely passionate and knowledgable about Criminal Law. He genuinely cares about students: there is no textbook to save money, he is available outside of class, and he makes sure everyone is on the same page in lecture. As a student with no prior exposure to the Criminal Law, Professor David was awesome!

I want to thanks for Professor David's whole year's teaching! I have greatly enjoyed and benefited from the classes that I took with him. He was the teacher who provides me the most help in my first-year law school. I sincerely thank him for the sharing of legal knowledge and for introducing to me that great movie!

Prof David is the man. His lectures are entertaining, his stories are illustrative, and his life story is wild. There's no textbook, only cases and criminal code provisions as readings. Attendance in lectures isn't mandatory, but considering all course content comes from what he says in lecture, they're basically mandatory.

Very charismatic professor. Always willing to answer questions after class or via email. He was always happy to help with all my exam questions via email and encouraged me to ask more if need be. All around good person.

Professor David is a passionate and caring educator. He held many review sessions throughout the course and responds to emails very quickly. His lectures are informative and covers the fundamentals of criminal law. I completed a criminal law internship this summer and used many of his lessons to put the cases in perspective.
Professor David is one of the most caring and compassionate profs. He is extremely knowledgeable, passionate about the course and hilarious. Great experience.

Point of 1L crim is not to teach how to do an SPI with a crim lawyer, it's to provide an intro to crim law & procedure, which prof LD did excellently. Invited legendary Supreme Court Justice Moldaver to speak which is epic. Truly cares about his students. altho no slides, sent out detailed class outlines. Engaging & thought provoking lectures. Take

I just finished a summer SPI with a criminal lawyer and realized how little I learned in LD's class about the foundations of criminal law! nice guy, but his inexperience and priorities show, since he was only a part-time professor and has a full time job! if you're interested in getting into criminal law as a career, i wouldn't recommend!

really nice professor and i thought it was going to be fun-filled and informative because i have always been interested in criminal law. i have worked in a bit of criminal law this summer and realized i didnt learn anything at all! wish i could have learned more practical stuff that would have made me more knowledgeable this summer.

Great instructor and a first-time teaching. He is very accessible and prompt in his response to emails; took Saturdays off to have extra lectures, has a funny laugh that makes everyone laugh. I get that the no-slides style is an issue with some; but second semester there was outlines provided and you can record the lectures too.

he is very passionate about crim law and it shows through his teaching. People who complained about no slides expect to be hand fed in law school. If you do the readings before hand, you will not be lost. In general, the readings are less than other courses. You really only need a summary of the case from google before going in.

Where to start. For a first time prof who claimed to really care about student feedback, he isn't too good at changing his behaviour/ teaching style. Numerous students complained that they would benefit from class slides or outlines instead of his random rambling about section 11 e... or wait, is it 11 c?? He doesn't even know, needs notes himself.

You know the man's brilliant when a Supreme Court Justice sings his praises. Exceptionally attentive to students' needs. Fair exams. Do the readings (much shorter than for other classes) and you won't be lost in class. Unprepared students will complain about having no slides, but if you have your own notes, you can follow along just fine!

not bad for a first time teacher! not using slides really hindered the learning experience. he can be a bit unprofessional, especially with his frequent and rambling emails, and spends too much time answering hypothetical questions. enjoyed his classes, but don't feel prepared for next level criminal law. hopefully he uses slides next year

unprofessional. doesn't use slides. notes don't even match the TA's. reports bad reviews. sends 100 emails. went to harvard, won't let you forget it. cute dog. has inappropriate banter with students. makes offensive jokes. very disorganized class and extremely different material from other large groups. full of himself. AVOID
Very nice man, terrible instructor. Make sure to read the text because his lectures are hard to keep up with because he doesnt use slides.

Amazing professor. Cares a lot about students and welcomes any feedback. Always available to answer your questions and will set up a lot of extra review sessions if you need them. There is no book for this class, all the cases are on the SCC website and he provides the link. Pay attention in class and read smart.

Taught Crim Law while Crowning for the Fed. Man can spit hot fiyah in a rap battle and spit hotter fiyah on Charter Defenses. Takes time to answer and explain sections well and clearly as well as the tests for them. No-slides format is good; but one big graph per lecture for visual learners though can help with teaching Crim Procedures.

I truly enjoyed the course and teaching style! It really helped me learn criminal law because Prof David encouraged open participation and discussion from the class which is really hard to do with 75 students. He was always encouraging and cared about student's professional development. Definitely a keeper at the University of Ottawa!!
